w:r.w:t: Gamified Coding & AI Classroom System — Full Spec (Semester 1)
Gamified layer + AI tutor + teacher console.
FK, type ENUM('PLAGIARISM','AI_ABUSE','FRAUD','OTHER'), weight INT, details JSONB,
, role, action, entity, before JSONB, after JSONB,
40% weighted by contribution (peer review + teacher logs)
Fallback → equal share if insufficient data
Tie-breakers: capstone XP > test XP > earlier first submission
Constraints supported (avoid pairs, lock pairs, min/max size)
UI: spin wheel or envelopes for suspense
Evidence export: rubric scores + student artifact links + CPALMS alignment
TIGHT (week corpus only), NORMAL (semester corpus), OPEN (rare)
Scaffold only, no full solutions for graded items
out-of-scope or flagged queries → teacher approval
spike detection (too many tutor calls, repeated out-of-scope, plagiarism flags)
XP anomalies (too many tutor events in burst)
teacher can override or clear flags
Tokenized parent/guardian portal: read-only badges, progress, showcase RSVP
Data retention: purge/anonymize 12 months after term
Metrics: XP distribution (Gini coefficient), leaderboard churn, badge unlock rates, tutor query volume, late penalties
job failures, >5% tutor HARD_BLOCK, suspicious XP bursts
Dashboards: teacher view (class health), admin view (program health)
Endpoints for assignments, submissions, XP events, badges, leaderboards, tutor queries, policy edits, Draft Day, moderation
Cron jobs: weekly leaderboard snapshot, badge awarder, plagiarism scan, standards coverage
Background jobs retry with exponential backoff
XP → redeem for perks (skip line, bonus hint packs)
deploy artifacts to GitHub Pages / student site
private progress rank for every student even if not
With these additions, you now have:
Core gamification (XP, badges, leaderboards, Draft Day).
AI tutor with teacher oversight + scope enforcement.
Integrity, fairness, privacy, accessibility, compliance safeguards.
classroom-ready, accreditation-friendly, parent-safe, and fun for kids
AI Tutor Oversight & Scope Control — Tech Addendum
(this week’s standards, lesson content, allowed tools).
: tutor unavailable; UI shows teacher note.
, no step-by-step for graded items; only definitions, rubric reminders, and references. Strict
: answers must cite (internally) a passage from
: (rare) allow broader CS basics but still enforce blocklist + tool whitelist.
Teacher toggles via console; changes apply immediately and are logged.
(fast text classifier or rules) → maps prompt to
, require a match above threshold (e.g., cosine ≥ 0.35).
→ regex/glob or semantic patterns (e.g., “write the entire assignment X”).
and assignment is active, refuse code, offer rubric-aligned guidance.
; show student: “Your question was sent to your teacher.”
4) Prompt Contract (server-side, never editable by students)
“You are a classroom tutor constrained to
If student asks for full code for graded tasks, reply with
, do not provide code; offer concepts, definitions, and rubric reminders only.
If out-of-scope, respond with: ‘That’s outside this week’s focus. Let’s connect it to {{
Regexes for “write my whole …”, “complete code”, “give entire solution”, “paste full program”, assignment titles, file names.
Length limits: if user asks for > N lines of code, downgrade to SNIPPET.
: detect if prompt includes ≥ X% of the assignment text.
“I can’t provide the entire solution, but here’s how to structure it…” + scaffold + 10-line max snippet.
“This goes beyond our current scope. Let’s stick to
6) Teacher Console (controls a real teacher needs)
: OFF / LEARN / ASSESS, with scope slider (TIGHT/NORMAL/OPEN).
: add/remove CPALMS codes & tags per week.
: stream of queries; click “Approve/Reject/Reply” for queued items.
: links an assignment id → switches to
: out-of-scope attempts, blocks, top topics, struggling students (quiz <70%).
(e.g., final answer keys) for graded prompts.
Replace disallowed URLs, libraries, or APIs not on whitelist.
(teacher email/UI): high out-of-scope rate, repeated HARD_BLOCK for the same student, sudden spikes in tutor usage.
: per-student transcript with assist levels (HINT/SNIPPET/EXAMPLE) for grading context.
rate limit, token max, reading level, bilingual glossaries.
; the tutor’s answer template can print the code (“This aligns with SC.912.CS-CP.1.2: loops and conditionals”) to reinforce standards.
I can help with concepts and rubric expectations, not code.”
“Great curiosity! For this week, let’s focus on {{
“I can’t provide the entire solution, but here’s a scaffold + key steps to help you build it yourself.”
Build query gateway with policy pipeline (Section 8).
